content:
There are situations in which a listview might seem to have too much of information. So I have built a custom list view component which is the customized version of the standard list view aura component.
   As shown in the image, the minimal list view removes most of the elements from the standard list view. It has a custom title, and an option to reset the width of the columns if altered by the user.
Now let’s jump to the coding part. If you already know how to create aura components in VS code, you can proceed with creating one and skip to this section.
Creating an Aura Component #    Ensure whether you have installed Salesforce recommended extensions in VS Code and you are connected to an org.   Press Ctrl + Shift + P and type aura Choose SFDX: Create Aura Component Provide your desired filename (minimalListViewAura in this post) and press Enter Provide the desired directory or just press Enter again Now the Aura component has been successfully created and ready to be built and customized.  Building the Minimal list view component # Copy the code into the corresponding files. minimalListViewAura.cmp
<aura:component implements="flexipage:availableForAllPageTypes" access="global"> <aura:attribute name="object" type="String" default="Account" /> <aura:attribute name="listName" type="String" default="Recent" /> <aura:attribute name="listTitle" type="String" default="Recent Accounts" /> <aura:attribute name="rows" type="Integer" default="5"/> <div style="position: relative;"> <h2 id="custom-list-title">{!v.listTitle}</h2> <lightning:listView objectApiName="{!v.object}" listName="{!v.listName}" rows="{!v.rows}" showSearchBar="false" showActionBar="false" enableInlineEdit="false" showRowLevelActions="false" /> <br /> </div> </aura:component>  minimalListViewAura.css
.THIS .infinite-loading, .THIS force-list-view-manager-status-info, .THIS force-list-view-manager-button-bar, .THIS .forceListViewSettingsMenu .slds-dropdown__header, .THIS .firstHeaderRow { display: none; } .THIS .errorColumnHeader, .THIS .errorColumn { display: none; } .THIS .forceListViewSettingsMenu { position: absolute; top: 5px; right: 10px; } .THIS .forceListViewSettingsMenu button { height: 27px; width: 35px; } .THIS #custom-list-title { position: absolute; top: 7px; left: 10px; z-index: 10; font-size: large; font-weight: bold; } That’s it! The minimal list view component is ready to be deployed to org.
 Right click on the component folder and choose SFDX: Deploy Source to Org After successful deployment, open the Org in Salesforce and on the desired app page, click on Edit Page option in the Gear icon at the right top of the page. As soon as the Lightning App Builder view has loaded, search for the component(minimalListViewAura) which we just deployed Drag and drop the component to the app page. The component fetches recently viewed accounts from Account object and displays the top 5 rows by default.     Using Minimal list view inside another aura component # The component which we now created can be injected into other aura components and reused for listviews in other objects. For example, if you want to view My Opportunities as a miinimal list view inside another aura component, insert the following code at the desired section inside your component.
<c:minimalListViewAura object="Opportunity" listName="MyOpportunities" listTitle="My Opportunities" rows="7" />       Visit the Salesforce Lightning Component Library to know more about Aura components and Lightning Web Components.
summary: There are situations in which a listview might seem to have too much of information.
title: Minimal List View using Aura Components

Create a react app
npm init react-app {react-app-name} Create an empty repository in GitHub with the same name of the react app.
git remote add origin https://github.com/{github-username}/{repo-name}    Note: Replace {github-username} with your GitHub username and {repo-name} with your repository name.  Install gh-pages package and save it as a dev dependency.
npm install gh-pages --save-dev In package.json, add this line
homepage: "https://{github-username}.github.io/{repository-name}", Under scripts, add these two lines
"predeploy": "npm run build", "deploy": "gh-pages -d build", Push all your code to the remote GitHub repository.
Now, run this command
npm run deploy On the browser, go to â†’ https://{github-username}.github.io/{repository-name}
Yay!!! Our react app is published using GitHub Pages! ðŸŽ‰
summary: In this post, I’ll share the steps to be followed to deploy a react app to github pages.
title: Deploying React App to GitHub Pages

Open Terminal using Ctrl + Alt + T or from the app launcher Navigate to the directory /usr/share/X11/xkb/symbols  cd /usr/share/X11/xkb/symbols Edit the file named pc as an administrator or root user
sudo gedit pc Identify the two keys which you want to swap.
   Note: You can only swap two keys here. You cannot assign same functionality to both the keys.  In my case, I have to swap the Right Control key and Right Shift key.
Now you can either log out and login or restart the shell by pressing Alt+F2 and running the restart command.
Thats it! You have remapped your keyboard keys successfully ðŸŽ‰

title: Remap Keys in Ubuntu [20.04]

content:
I’m Harish K and I’m pursuing my B.Tech in Computer Science and Engineering at Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham (2018-2022). I have been selected as a Software Engineer at Cisco, India. I’m happy to share my interview experience and I hope you’ll enjoy it.
Online Round # In this round, I dealt with questions from the following domains:
 Aptitude Basics of Cryptography Computer Networks Data Structures & Algorithms DBMS Operating Systems  I took the online MCQ and coding test in the morning, and the results of the same were published on the same evening. Candidates who have cleared this round are invited to join a Webex Space, where all important announcements regarding the interview process will be made.
The whole interview process happened via Webex the next day, and it consisted of three rounds â€” Technical round, Managerial round and HR round.
Technical Round # This was an interesting round. I was asked about each of the projects that I’ve put in my resume. It is a very important section of our interview, as the answers for the questions reveal the depth of our knowledge on our projects. Having a proper and clear understanding of the concepts on the projects in our resume will help us answer such questions with confidence.
There were two or three occasions where I was not sure of the answer. But I expressed my thought process for those questions, as it is important for the interviewer to know how you think. I was asked questions from various domains such as DBMS, Java, Python and Web development. At the end of an hour, the round completed with some basic non-technical questions.
Managerial Round # This round was relaxed and chill compared to the first round. I was asked questions which test our decision-making ability. I got to share some situations where things went in a way which wasn’t expected, and how I overcame them. I was also asked why I chose to be in Cisco. Lastly, I got to know the work-life balance in Cisco from my interviewers.
HR Round # This was also a cool round where I was asked some questions about the company and its goals. Then I was asked for priority of locations to work and at last, I was conveyed the details of the role, stipend and CTC.
The interview process started at 8:00 am and I completed all the rounds at around 5:00 pm. Then in the evening of the same day, the results of the interview process were announced.
My Thoughts # The interview experience was amazing and I learned a lot. I did face a little difficulty with keeping up with the interview announcements as all shortlisted candidates were included in the same space in Webex and each of us received our invitations from that single location. Other than that, the overall experience was great. The interviewers were kind and amicable.
Things that helped me # Invlove in challenges which allow you to acquire the skill of solving problems on a daily basis. My #100DaysOfCode challenge helped me a lot. Also, ask all possible questions to yourself whenever you are learning important concepts. Last but not the least, if things didn’t happen as expected, do not lose the spirit, keep up the positive attitude and work harder. Things will turn out in your favour.
 Believe in yourself!
summary: In this post, I’ll share the experience on my first interview with Cisco.
title: My First Interview
